Kolumna Marije M. Kotnik: Žalostni Dejan, še bolj žalostni Slovenci
Praznovanje vsakoletne prve uporabe slovenskega jezika bi moralo vsekakor biti veselo, prisrčno in navdihujoče.
07 Nov 2019, 09:10 by Marija Mica Kotnik



Primož se z Dejanom najbrž ne bi ujel. FOTO: ARHIV



Otožni in nič kaj navdihujoči Dejan FOTO: VORANC VOGEL/DELO


Ko sem na predvečer dneva reformacije poslušala predsednika državnega zbora Dejana Židana, ki je z otožnim, skorajda pogrebniškim izrazom na licu sredi odra Linhartove dvorane Cankarjevega doma dejal, da »obeležujemo prelom časa in civilizacijski preskok v kulturnem in jezikovnem popotovanju slovenskega naroda«, sem, priznam, morala skočiti tja, kamor gre še cesar peš.Praznovanje vsakoletne prve uporabe slovenskega jezika bi moralo vsekakor biti veselo, prisrčno in navdihujoče.Vrnila sem se, ko je našteval, s takistim izrazom, kako je reformacija kot gibanje pričevala času, ko je kompleks družbenih dilem močno polariziral takratno družbo. Nenadomestljivo je vplivala na versko, politično, družbeno in kulturno sliko Evrope, ki se je začela izvijati iz preteklih težkih spon v nov preporod. Izjemni posamezniki, kot so Primož Trubar, Jurij Dalmatin, Adam Bohorič in Sebastijan Krelj, so ta preporod znali povezati s potrebami naroda.Reformatorji so po besedah slavnostnega govornika s svojim delovanjem vselej dokazovali, da ni nasprotja med iskrenim prizadevanjem za izboljšanje usode lastnega naroda, kulture in jezika ter širino evropskega duha in njegove različnosti.Povedal je tudi, da skrb za ohranjanje našega jezika ne pomeni zapiranja ali ograjevanja odprtosti našega duha, ampak »zmoremo in moramo skrb za ohranjanje lastnega jezika ter razvoj in napredek našega naroda izkazovati drugače«.


Primož se z Dejanom najbrž ne bi ujel. FOTO: ARHIV

Kaj je hotel povedati, ne vem. Vem le, da je sledila proslava, ki je bila bolj podobna praznovanju dneva pozneje, dneva mrtvih, kot pa proslavi, s katero bi častili in se veselili lastnega jezika. Le zakaj se niso veselili lastnemu jeziku, lastni kulturi, sem se vprašala v nekem trenutku …Kulturniki že vrsto let opozarjajo na dokaj nevzdržne razmere, pa tudi da je v sistemsko podprti kulturi pravzaprav vse v najlepšem redu – dokler seveda »mi« in ne »kdo drug« zasedamo položaje in si »mi« ne »kdo drug« delimo denar in »mi« in ne »kdo drug« odločamo o tem, kaj so osrednja, razvojna, tendenciozna in še kakšna pomembna vprašanja in kaj ne, kot je pred dnevi v odlični kolumni med drugim o poraznem stanju v slovenski kulturi, natančneje v enemu od slovenskih gledališč, napisala novinarka Dela Ženja Leiler.Kot se mi zdi, se takšni ali drugačni t. i. apeli obupa že nekaj let vrstijo od različnih skupin, ki jim je mar tako za slovenski jezik in kulturo; bodisi so to jezikoslovci, književniki, gledališčniki ali glasbeniki. Izboljšanja stanja seveda ni. To je le še dokaz več, da je izbrancem naroda, tistim, ki so jih polna usta kulture, ohranjanja lastnega, slovenskega jezika in vsega podobnega, kar pač gre poleg, povsem vseeno, ali govorci na javnih prireditvah spregovorijo v zbirokratizirani slovenščini, pomešani s srbohrvatizmi, ali kako drugače. Skoraj prepričana sem, da bi dežurni dušebrižniki obmolknili tudi, če bi kak govorec spregovoril v tonganščini.


Otožni in nič kaj navdihujoči Dejan FOTO: VORANC VOGEL/DELO

Saj pravim, če se ne zmoremo ceniti sami, nas ne bo cenil nihče.Še bolj sem prepričana, da o pomenu jezika za obstoj naroda govorimo največkrat enkrat ali dvakrat na leto, ko je kakšen praznik. Sicer nam je, kot se zdi, za slovenščino figo mar. Pred približno dvema letoma (ah, ta lepa slovenska dvojina) sem na radiu zasledila pogovor s slovenistko, ki dela v Celovcu, doktorico humanističnih znanosti Maruško Agrež, ki je med drugim dejala: »Slovenci, ki živimo ali smo rojeni v matični državi, se premalo zavedamo pomena slovenščine, ki nas predstavlja kot narod. In kot se zdi, se te druge dimenzije včasih bolj zavedajo Slovenci v zamejstvu ali po svetu kot tisti doma.«In ne bi se mogla bolj strinjati z njo. Kot se je izrazila, bi slovenski narod lahko poimenovali kar The Slovenes, radi torej rečemo, da smo Slovenci, vendar v tujem jeziku.No, se mi pa vsekakor zdi, da bi moralo biti praznovanje vsakoletne prve uporabe slovenskega jezika veselo, prisrčno in navdihujoče. Navsezadnje smo tako Slovenci v resnici postali tudi narod. Dobili smo svoj jezik.Zato bi bilo nekako res tudi za pričakovati, da bi morda predsednik državnega zbora Dejan Židan svoj govor ob dnevu reformacije res prebral z bolj veselim izrazom na obrazu. Razen če je vedel, kar mi še ne vemo, da bo prihodnje leto taista proslava potekala v katerem drugem jeziku!

Mary M. Kotnik's column: Sad Dejan, even sadder Slovenes
Celebrating every year's first use of the Slovenian language should definitely be fun, heartfelt and inspiring.
07 Nov 2019, 09:10 by Marija Mica Kotnik



Primoz would probably not catch up with Dejan. PHOTO: ARCHIVE



The deplorable and nothing inspiring Dejan PHOTO: VORANC VOGEL / WORK


When I listened to National Assembly Speaker Dejan Židan on the eve of the Reformation Day, saying with a sorrowful, almost funeral expression on the face of the stage of Linhart Hall of Cankar's House, that "we are marking a turning point and a civilization leap in the cultural and linguistic journey of the Slovenian nation," I admit, I had to jump to where the Emperor was going on foot. Celebrating the first ever use of the Slovene language should definitely be cheerful, heartfelt and inspiring. I came back when he enumerated with the expression how the Reformation as a movement witnessed a time when the complex of social dilemmas greatly polarized society at the time. It has irreplaceably influenced the religious, political, social and cultural image of Europe, which has begun to wriggle out of past difficult staples into a new revival. Exceptional individuals such as Primoz Trubar, Yuri Dalmatin, Adam Bohoric and Sebastian Krelj knew how to relate this rebirth to the needs of the nation. According to a celebrity speaker, reformers have always shown that there is no conflict between a sincere effort to improve the fate of their own nation, culture and language and the breadth of the European spirit and its diversity. He also said that the concern for preserving our language does not mean closing or fencing the openness of our spirit, but "we can and must take care of preserving our own language and developing and advancing our nation differently."


Primoz would probably not catch up with Dejan. PHOTO: ARCHIVE

I don't know what he wanted to say. All I know is that it was a celebration that was more like celebrating the day after, the day of the dead, than a celebration to honor and rejoice in our own language. Why did they not rejoice in their own language, their own culture, I wondered at some point ... For many years, culturists have been pointing out the rather intolerable situation, but also that in a system-supported culture, everything is in the best order - until of course "we" and not " who else "occupy positions and" we "do not" who else "share the money and" we "and not" who else "decide what are the central, developmental, tendentious and other important issues and what not, as before days in an excellent column, among other things, about the devastating situation in Slovenian culture, more specifically in one of the Slovenian theaters, wrote the journalist Dela Zenja Leiler. i. Appeals of despair have for several years been drawn from different groups that care about the Slovenian language and culture; be it linguists, writers, theaters or musicians. Of course, there is no improvement. This is just more proof that to the elect of the nation, to those who are full of the mouth of culture, to preserve their own, Slovene language and all that, which goes besides, it is completely irrelevant whether the speakers at public events speak in bureaucratized Slovene mixed with Serb Croats, but otherwise. I am almost certain that on-duty nightshades would be silent even if a speaker spoke in Tongan.


The deplorable and nothing inspiring Dejan PHOTO: VORANC VOGEL / WORK

I say, if we cannot value ourselves, no one will appreciate us. I am even more convinced that we speak about the importance of language for the existence of a nation most often once or twice a year, when it is a holiday. Otherwise, we seem to care about the Slovenian figure. About two years ago (ah, this beautiful Slovenian duality), I found a conversation on the radio with a Slovenian doctor who works in Klagenfurt, Doctor of Humanities Maruška Agrež, who said, among other things: "Slovenians living or born in their home country we are too little aware of the importance of Slovenian, which represents us as a nation. And as it seems, these other dimensions are sometimes more aware of Slovenes abroad or abroad than at home. ”And I couldn't agree more with her. As she put it, the Slovenian nation could be called The Slovenes, so we want to say that we are Slovenians, but in a foreign language. Well, it certainly seems to me that the celebration of the first use of the Slovenian language should be joyful, warm and inspiring. . After all, we Slovenes have in fact become a nation. We got our own language. That is why it would also be true to expect that the Speaker of the National Assembly, Dejan Židan, might really read his speech on the day of the Reformation with a more cheerful expression on his face. Unless he knew what we didn't know yet, this year's celebration would be in another language!
